questions.question: Is the clock face present on the upper section of the left bell tower?
questions.explanation: In Image B, examining the left bell tower reveals no clock face on the upper section; instead, it shows an open window-like space with an arch. This can be contrasted with typical bell tower designs that may incorporate a clock, but Image B lacks such an element. Upon comparing with Image A, it is evident that Image A includes a distinctive clock face in that location, which is absent in Image B.

questions.question: Are there two bells visible in the arches of the right bell tower?
questions.explanation: Image B shows a singular bell visible within the arches of the right bell tower. Architectural designs often incorporate a space for one or more bells, but Image B specifically displays one. Comparing with Image A shows two separate bells in the corresponding arches, confirming that Image B lacks one of the bells present in Image A.

questions.question: Is there a circular stained-glass window with a floral or star-like pattern centered above the main entrance?
questions.explanation: Within Image B, the central part of the façade above the entrance showcases a circular stained-glass window with a decorative pattern, typically found in cathedral designs to provide a focal point and light filtration. A comparison with Image A confirms the presence of a similarly styled window, indicating this element is common to both images.

questions.question: Is there a cross positioned at the highest point of the central roofline?
questions.explanation: Image B depicts a cross situated at the peak of the central roofline, which is a common feature for cathedrals, symbolizing Christianity. By comparing with Image A, a similar cross can be observed in the same position, confirming its presence in both images.

questions.question: Are there three doors on the façade: one large central door and two smaller side doors?
questions.explanation: Image B portrays the façade with a dominant central entrance flanked by two smaller doors, forming a typical tripartite design commonly seen in grand architectural entrances. Image A similarly displays such an arrangement of doors, reinforcing the observation that the same design is consistent across both images.

questions.question: Is the façade symmetrically divided by vertical columns and pilasters?
questions.explanation: Image B's façade is marked by a symmetrical structure, divided by columns and pilasters, achieving balance and structural integrity, a characteristic of classic architectural designs. Evaluating Image A also shows a comparable symmetrical organization with matching structural elements, confirming this feature's consistency between both images.

questions.question: Does the left bell tower have a pinkish dome with a cross on top?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the upper section of the left bell tower includes a dome with a pinkish hue crowned by a cross, which serves both decorative and religious purposes. Comparing to Image A, one observes the same pinkish dome with a cross, signifying this detail is unchanged between the two images.

questions.question: Is there a multi-story building with balconies and wrought-iron railings to the right of the cathedral?
questions.explanation: Visual analysis of Image B reveals a building adjacent to the right of the cathedral, which displays balconies fitted with wrought-iron railings, a typical urban architectural feature for multi-story buildings. Image A depicts an identical structure with the same elements, affirming its presence in both images.
